Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tectonic and Magmatic Processes during Early-Stage Rifting: an Integrated Study of Northern Lake Malawi, Africa
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although the concept that thick continental lithosphere extends and ultimately ruptures has been accepted for over 50 years, the conditions required for this to occur and the factors that are most important in controlling the style of rifting, the formation and maintenance of tectonic segmentation and the initiation of magmatism remain contentious. This is especially true of the earliest stages of extension, in part because most studies focus on successfully rifted margins and mature rifts, where extensive stretching, syn- and post-rift magmatism, and post-breakup sedimentation overwrite and bury the record of incipient extension. Understanding how, why and when features that are characteristic of mid-ocean ridges and rifts first form and evolve during early rifting is essential for a broader understanding of plate divergence.

The primary scientific goal of this project is to examine the emergence and early evolution of two fundamental features of all divergent plate boundaries: magmatism and segmentation. Magmatism accommodates a significant percentage of plate separation at most mid-ocean ridges and late-stage rifts. Likewise, transform faults demarcate discrete spreading segments in mid-ocean ridges, which are broadly
characterized by more robust magmatism at their centers than at their edges. Well-developed magmatic and tectonic segmentation is also observed in late-stage rifts and new ocean basins However,little is known about the controls on the initiation and development of magmatism and segmentation in young rifts. Specifically, th PIs seek to address the following questions:

? When, where and why does magmatism initiate in rifts, and what is its role in accommodating extension?
? What controls the development of tectonic segmentation in early-stage rifts? How is it manifested in 4D patterns of magmatism
and deformation.

The project consists of an integrated geophysical, geochemical and geological study of the northern Lake Malawi region in the East African Rift System (EARS) to address these questions. This is one of the few places in the world that has all of the ingredients necessary for a comprehensive study of early rifting. Active and passive seismic data and MT data will reveal the 3D structure of the crust and lithosphere at a variety of length scales, from the architecture of border faults and accommodation zones to the distribution of deformation and magma (if present) in the mantle lithosphere. Surface deformation, seismicity, and rift stratigraphy, as well as geochronology, thermobarometry and geochemistry of volcanic rocks, will yield constraints on the origin of magmatism and the evolution of deformation and magmatism at a range of time scales, including possibly variable contributions from sub-lithospheric versus lithospheric sources. Comparisons of active and cumulative deformation patterns will enable the evaluation of the importance of episodicity, seismicity and magmatism in accommodating extension and how they relate to segmentation. This powerful combination of temporal and spatial constraints will produce unique insights into the initiation of segmentation and magmatism during continental rifting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key part of the plate tectonic cycle is continental breakup, where a continent is stretched, thinned and ultimately rifts apart to form a new ocean basin.  For example, these geological processes lead to the formation of the Atlantic Ocean 200 million years ago.  Nonetheless, there are many questions about how continental thinning and breakup actually occur, particularly during the early stages. How does the continent thin at different depths?  Does magma help weaken the continent and thus assist continental breakup? Active continental rifts produce earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, so are also important to understand for geohazards.  We undertook a large study of the northern Malawi Rift, an early stage rift at the southern end of the East Africa Rift System.  Part of the rift is covered by Lake Malawi, one of the largest freshwater lakes in the world. A cluster of volcanos lies north of the lake. The Malawi Rift is seismically and volcanically active; relatively large earthquakes occurred in 2009 and 2014 and impacted local communities. Our study involved using geophysical methods to create images of the upper 150 km of the Earth, recording earthquakes and ground motion, and analyzing volcanic rocks.

The upper ~25 miles of the continent extend by breaking, forming faults and causing earthquakes. The Malawi Rift is bound by faults that are up to 90 miles long with massive 1.25-mile-high escarpments. By imaging geology below Lake Malawi, we were able to determine that 5.5 miles of total motion had occurred on these faults, making them some of the largest faults of their kind in the world. In addition to these very large faults, we imaged many other faults hidden below the lake. Though much smaller than the big faults bounding the rift, they still appear to have been important to rift opening. By recording tiny earthquakes with sensitive seismometers, we can figure out which faults are active and could produce large, destructive earthquakes in the future. We found that many of these faults host tiny earthquakes and should be considered for hazards.  

Deeper in the earth, temperatures and pressures are too high for rocks to break, so instead thinning of the continent occurs by stretching rather than breaking. We were able to image earth structure down to ~100 miles using both sound waves from distant earthquakes and electromagnetic currents.  Analyses of these data show that the continent has stretched and thinned more than we would have expected, with most thinning centered beneath the surface expression of the rift and with more thinning of deep layers than shallow ones.   This result is very important because it suggests that thinning and weakening of the continent occurs from the bottom up.

Although the only volcanos in the region are north of the lake, we wanted to learn if magma might be hidden below the surface away from the volcanos and be helping to weaken the continent.  Our imaging of the deeper part of the continent with sound waves shows that the only magma present below ground is centered beneath the volcanos and is not found elsewhere today.  However, the fact that deep layers have thinned more than shallow layers suggests that small amounts of magma may have helped weaken the continent in the past. 

Analysis of the rocks from the volcanos shows that they have been there for 19 millions years, which is older than some previous estimates. Another question we had before our study was the origin of magmas. Do they come from a hot plume of material deep in the earth or do they form more shallowly? Our analyses show that the magmas did not form at extraordinarily hot temperatures, but they did originate below the continent and have tracers of very deep material. However, on their ascent to the surface, their composition was modified as they interacted with the surrounding continental rocks.

Finally, we also wanted to know how fast the rift was opening and over what area. By measuring very precise locations with GPS equipment installed on either side of the rift, we find that it is opening very slowly ? only ~2 mm/yr.  The GPS show that extension today is occurring over a surprisingly wide area compared to the narrow surface expression of the rift.

Put together, our study has painted a very complete portrait of how continental thinning is happening in the Malawi Rift and the associated hazards. We addressed several key questions, and can apply many of the lessons we have learned here to other active and ancient rift systems around the world.  This project provided opportunities for US graduate students and several undergraduate interns to receive training in geological processes, data analysis methods, and quantitative analysis in general. This project also led to the formation and strengthening of international partnerships between scientists in the US, Malawi and Tanzania.
